pros: Really great vibe with the team. Manager was very supportive.
cons: Need more resources, but management were looking into it before I left.

job_title: Community Access Worker in London, England
pros: Had a good manager that guided me
cons: higher up were more goal driven rather than person centered

job_title: Deputy Project Manager in London, England
pros: Flexible, varied shifts, good supervision structure and great values.
cons: Limited career progression, minimum wage and financial benefits.

review_title: Outreach Support Worker with adults with varying learning disabilities.
job_title: Relief Outreach Support Worker in Braintree, England
pros: I didnt need experience of care industry.  Ongoing training some online modules. My team leader and colleagues very supportive.  On call manager for support if you have difficulties with a service user especially out of office hours.  The Service Users are great.! The work is sometimes challenging, always tiring (but fun as well) but this is a positive as you learn people skills you didnt know you had.  Feeling of doing something worthwhile - helping people access the community and develop life skills which they wouldn't if they were stuck in an institution. On training days you meet other likeminded people from other projects which is great for swapping notes.  Travel costs incurred between service users and all travelling to training is fully refunded.   I can work around family committments.
cons: Initial training always takes place in head office in London and ongoing training too.  If you are in Essex this can be a bit of a trek and a very long day.

pros: if there is any problem at work they are ready to help
cons: no career progression, no wage increase
